Yaâ€™ll know Iâ€™m a sucker for a good greek mythology re-telling & Ariadne is definitely not disappointing so far
.
Ariadne, princess of Crete is the daughter of King Minos and the sister of Asterion, who is much better known as the Minotaur (half man, half bull). Growing up hearing the growls and hoofbeats of her brother in the labyrinth below the palace, and witnessing those sacrificed to his bloody appetite each year, this book is ultimately the story of Ariadneâ€™s betrayal of her family and Crete when she reveals to her lover, Theseus, how to slay her brother the Minotaur.
.
In a world ruled by ruthless gods, Ariadne knows all too well what drawing their attention can mean for her fate. - I CANNOT WAIT TO FINISH THIS BOOK (& then discuss with @the.lowreylibrary) ğŸ¤©
.
If you love Greek mythology definitely pick this one up!

Do you annotate your books?
.
I typically annotate and use sticky tabs while reading classic or very large books - it helps me easily turn back to quotes/scenes that I enjoyed, new vocabulary, when new characters are introduced, etc! When itâ€™s a very large book (like The Count of Monte Cristo pictured here) I also mark every 100 pages! I find that annotating books makes the story more meaningful to me, and helps me stay engaged/focused while reading.
.
ALSO! @bookishlifeofabby recently made me a rep for her small business @bibliopressed and I couldnâ€™t be more honored/excited to be a part of her team. This small canvas pouch is the perfect size to keep all my book annotating items!!! Plus, the designs she creates are up every book loverâ€™s alley. DUNE ğŸŒ“ Frank Herbert
.
Set thousands of years in the future, Dune begins the story of young Paul Atreides, heir to a noble family, as he & his family prepare to move to the desert planet, Arrakis (aka Dune), to rule, as declared by the Emperor. 
.
Arrakis is a challenging, inhospitable planet where the only thing more valuable than water is the â€˜spiceâ€™ melange, an awareness spectrum narcotic that is able to enhance oneâ€™s consciousness and extend oneâ€™s life. But it is also very addictive making the eyes (iris + sclera) of those who consume it stained blue & has lethal withdrawal symptoms.
.
The spice is fundamental for commerce & is necessary for space travel by enabling navigators to safely guide space ships through warp space. The spice can only be harvested on Arrakis, and therefore is heavily valued, capable of sustaining or destroying the empire.
.
However, Paul & the Atredies family have been brought to Arrakis under false pretenses & are betrayed. The destruction of his family and his people sets Paul along a journey towards his destiny of becoming the mysterious â€˜Muadâ€™Dibâ€™ and leading the Arrakis natives, The Fremen.
.
This book is sci-fi gold. I loved it so much. I will say the first couple chapters are extremely dense and therefore slow, as Herbert dumps the reader into a whole new world with strange names, words and hierarchies. You WILL NEED THE APPENDIX! I was so intimidated by the first few chapters because I had no idea what was going on - but Iâ€™m so glad I pushed through and continued to read. I also watched a small crash-course on YouTube of how the world of Dune is set up/how it came to be - really helped me out.
.
After pushing through the confusion, this book has so many amazing things about it: a coming of age story that tackles politics, religion, environmentalism and climate change. It is good vs evil & has deep characters that are interesting to explore and love. Plus is has giant sandworms that you can ride (if youâ€™re skilled enough not to die first). This book is the cornerstone of science-fiction. ğŸœ canâ€™t wait for the film adaptation!

Currently reading: DUNE ğŸœ
.
AND LOVING IT! You know what else Iâ€™m loving? My â€œRead A Bookâ€ sweatshirt from @inkwellthreads & the fact that itâ€™s sunny & I can feel warm weather coming! I miss reading outside!
.
I have about 100 pages left in Dune & I honestly am so happy I started this series. (Thanks for buddy reading with me @maryhadalittlenook). The detail that went into the world building is incredible and so interesting. I cannot wait to read the other books and see the movie when it comes out this fall! Book review for DUNE will be coming soon!
.
Is it sunny where you all are? Do you enjoy reading outside? ğŸ˜

Catch-22 âœˆï¸ Joseph Heller
.
â€œOpen your eyes, it doesnâ€™t make a damned bit of difference who wins the war to someone whoâ€™s dead.â€ 
.
This story follows Yossarian, a young bombardier in the United States Army stationed in Italy during WWII. Yossarian is trying to make it through the war alive, and is absolutely furious that there are so many people (most that he doesnâ€™t know) trying to kill him.
.
Yossarian quickly discovers that it is not just the Nazi Germans who are out to get him, but the leaders of his own squadron who continue to raise the number of combat missions men must fly before they can be sent home. Then, of course there is the catch, Catch-22.
.
Catch-22 states that any man that is deemed to be insane can be grounded and not fly anymore combat missions, but concern for oneâ€™s own safety in the face of danger is the process of a rational mind.
.
In summary, a soldier who continues to fly into combat of his own accord is considered crazy and is eligible to be grounded, all he has to do is ask. BUT, as soon as that same soldier asks to not fly anymore missions, he would no longer be crazy and would therefore have to fly more missions. 
.
This book is without a doubt one of the most bitterly hilarious, wonderfully witty novels I have ever read. Full of satire and cynicism this book portrays and exposes the insane world of war and the military mindset. This book shows the side of war the general public fails to think about: how it unhinges and flips morals, whatâ€™s right and wrong - everything you think you know - upside down. So many important and serious themes emerge through the satire and humor as our narrator, Yossarian, attempts to make sense of the war which in and of itself is senseless. 
.
Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed Catch-22. I laughed out loud many times and used tons of stickies to mark notable quotes. While this book isnâ€™t perfect, being repetitive and harder to follow all the characters in the beginning & the flow of the book can be hard to get into at times, Iâ€™ve never read a single book like this & Iâ€™m very happy to add this American classic novel to my read pile. 4 â­ï¸

Introducing the #BigBookLovin challenge ğŸ¤©ğŸ“š
.
So often these thick, beautiful beauties catch our eye in bookstores, but they rarely get off our shelves once we bring them home
.
I want bookstagram to show some lovin to their favorite big books & try and break the intimidation surrounding reading them! Whether it takes you a week, a month or a year to finish one of these doorstoppers, IT DOESNâ€™T MATTER! 
.
Iâ€™ve seen a lot of amazing things on bookstagram, but Iâ€™ve also seen some disappointing things. Some wonâ€™t pick up their large books because they are afraid they wonâ€™t make their monthly quota. Why are we making reading into a job?! Itâ€™s a hobby & one that shouldnâ€™t involve competition. All the pressure and BS readers put on themselves or others to read a certain amount of books, etc. needs to end. Reading is for everyone no matter how fast/slow you get through books, no matter how many books you read a year - it looks different on each person and thatâ€™s ğŸ’¯ okay.
.
Iâ€™m guilty of this too - so many times Iâ€™ve skipped over my big books because I think it will take up too much time to read them and I will fall behind on my â€œgoal.â€ Well Iâ€™m tired of that type of thinking & I want to embrace my big books & dive into the wonderful stories Iâ€™ve been missing! I challenge everyone to pick up a large book youâ€™ve been avoiding and break the reading stigmas on bookstagram. This challenge is open to ANYONE! ğŸ¤©

A Thousand Ships ğŸº Natalie Haynes
.
An incredible feminist take on Greek mythology and the classic tales of the Trojan War and The Odyssey. This book gives these women (who weâ€™ve read so much about their husbands) a voice. We get to experience their suffering, their anger, their bravery and their losses..
.
Tales of women like Penelope [wife of Odysseus], Hecabe [wife of Priam & Queen of Troy] and her daughters, Clemnestra [wife of Agamemnon] & many many more women who are typically written in the shadow of men, are now center stage in this story & I loved reading every chapter of it.
.
This book give women dimension, unlike the stoic natures they possess in past books written about the same topic. Natalie Haynes has somehow made reading a well-known story feel brand new. I was very impressed and will definitely be reading more by her in the future. ğŸº this book gets all the â­ï¸s from me.
.
This picture is supposed to represent Aphrodite holding the Golden Apple. As the story goes, the goddesses Aphrodite, Hera & Athena commanded Paris, prince of Troy, to choose the most beautiful among them and gift her the golden apple. Aphrodite promised Paris the most beautiful woman in the world [Helen of Sparta] & thus when Paris stole her away to Troy, The Trojan War was initiated.

Pour me a cup of knowledge, Iâ€™ve had enough caffeine ğŸ“–â˜•ï¸
.

Brood ğŸ£ Jackie Polzin
.
Thank you @doubledaybooks for the ARC in exchange for an honest review! 
.
Brood was a compelling story that reads very smoothly on the surface, almost like private journal entries. However, this story is anything but simple, tackling heavy, emotional topics under the surface. 
.
A woman who has recently experienced a miscarriage, hides her grief by obsessing over the safety and care of her four chickens - seemingly trying to convince herself that she is worthy and capable of caring for another living thing. With her husband oblivious to her inner grieving, our nameless narrator attempts to focus on anything but her great loss. She strives to keep her chickens alive through a bitter Minnesota winter, a summertime tornado & the creatures that hunt at night. She has to prove to herself she can provide for these 4 animals.
.
This is a very realistic & moving story of one trying to pave the way through despair towards hope of new possibilities.

âœ¨ A Saturday spent at bookstores is a Saturday well spent âœ¨
.

Eenie Meenie Miney Mo,
Choose a book or let it go.
Will this book be friend or foe?
Thereâ€™s only one way to know.
.
WUTHERING HEIGHTS!! Youâ€™ve been chosen as my next classic read! (ignore the subpar poem skills lol).

The Midnight Library â™Ÿ Matt Haig
.
â€œLife sometimes simply gave you a whole new perspective by waiting around long enough to see it.â€
.
In Nora Seedâ€™s opinion, sheâ€™d rather be dead. Misery & despair have dominated her years and she can never shake the feeling that sheâ€™s repeatedly let everyone in her life down, including herself. On one particularly bad day, Nora decides to end it.
.
However, as Nora comes to find out, between life & death there is a library - The Midnight Library, to be exact, with the librarian being a beloved individual of her past. The Midnight Library houses endless volumes - all different versions of how your life could have been if youâ€™d made different choices.
.
Nora begins to explore the libraryâ€™s contents firsthand, able to transport directly into these parallel/perpendicular universes, where she attempts to undo each decision sheâ€™s ever regretted. But she does not have forever to decide. Before time runs out she must choose: which is the perfect life? What is the best way to live?
.
Okay, this will without a doubt be one of my favorite books in 2021. This story is quick paced (I read in less than 24 hours), heart-felt, and offers very important lessons about your outlook on life. As someone who constantly wonders how my life couldâ€™ve turned out differently if I made different choices, this book hit special with me. With nods to great philosophers, Haig explores the meaning of life & provides important insight which the reader can carry forward into his/her own life.
.
â€œIt is easy to mourn lives we arenâ€™t living. Easy to wish weâ€™d developed other talents, said yes to different offers. Easy to wish weâ€™d worked harder, loved better, handled finances more astutely, stayed in the band, said yes to coffee or done more bloody yoga...itâ€™s easy to regret, and keep regretting...until our time runs out.â€

The Da Vinci Code ğŸ¥€ Dan Brown
.
Robert Langdon, the renowned American symbologist is awoken suddenly in the night from his Paris hotel room where he is currently visiting on business, to some terrible news. The curator of the Louvre has been murdered inside the museum and left a cipher which has the French police absolutely baffled.
.
Joined and aided by the French cryptologist, Sophie Neveu, Langdon begins to reveal a trail of many clues hidden, several in the works of Leonardo Da Vinci right inside the museum. But with Langdon being the prime suspect of the curatorâ€™s murder, there is not much time to sit and think.
.
As clue after clue reveals more information, Neveu and Langdon discover that the curator was a member of the Priory of Sion - an ancient secret religious society whose main purpose is to protect an extremely important religious relic - most importantly keeping it out of the hands of the Catholic Church.
.
In a heart-racing chase that leads from Paris to London, Langdon and Neveu work to discover the answers to the puzzle, all the while being hunted by the French authorities & an Opus Dei (Catholic extremist) monk. If the secret falls into the wrong hands, it will be lost forever.
.
So, I figured it was about time I read this controversial book! Growing up in the Christian faith, I was curious to see what had everyone buzzing about this book many years ago. My mom advised me before I began to simply read this book for what it is, which is FICTION. And I personally enjoyed this story tremendously.
.
I absolutely loved the setting: Europe has my heart so I enjoy any book set in that continent. Secondly, I LOVE a good treasure hunt where a series of clues must be solved. As far as how the Catholic faith is portrayed, again, this book is fiction & I donâ€™t think Brown was encouraging readers to go away from the faith. He simply was creating a story of something that could have been, expanding the possibilities of reality and religion.
.
Summed up, this book was witty & extremely fast-paced with short chapters that allowed me to race through & there is a ton of historical, art and religious history that I absolutely loved learning more about.

Hamilton: The Revolution â­ï¸ Lin Manuel Miranda & Jeremy McCarter
.
Iâ€™ve been obsessed with Hamilton the musical for several years but this book was everything I never knew I needed. Just reading everything that went into the process of creating such a genius masterpiece was mind blowing. Going through each of the songs & reading Linâ€™s little comments about his particular word choice, his references to other artists, etc. somehow made me feel like I was discovering Hamilton for the first time all over again.
.
If you are already a fan of the show, read this book immediately - It will only fuel your obsession. If you have yet to jump on the Hamilton fan train, definitely listen to some of the music and see how you like it. Itâ€™s so carefully and creatively crafted with every single line serving a specific purpose, itâ€™s impossible not to be impressed. I mean, writing ACCURATE United States history into a hip-hop/rap musical while still entertaining people seems like an impossible feat - but Lin Manuel blew that challenge out of the water. A show this incredible comes maybe once a generation.
.
ALSO just realized today is my 2 year anniversary since seeing the show! ğŸ˜

The Martian ğŸš€ Andy Weir
.
So picture Tom Hanks â€œCastawayâ€ but switch the island setting to planet Mars. When an unexpected dust storm forces the crew of the Ares 3 mission to evacuate the planet early, Mark is presumed to be dead & the rest of the crew start the journey back to Earth. BUT, Mark Watney is miraculously alive & all alone with no way to signal to Earth that he survived.
.
His only chance of rescue are the Ares 4 mission due to land on Mars in 4 years. But his supplies will run out way before that date and heâ€™ll starve...if the unforgiving Mars environment and failing equipment donâ€™t kill him first. Mark is forced to put his mechanical engineering & botany skills to work to stay alive and find some way of communication. This book is the story of his struggle to survive.
.
This book was awesome! Watneyâ€™s character was the perfect snarky, sharp-witted and sarcastic narrator & I found myself laughing out loud multiple times throughout this story! While I found Weir to be very scientific and technical throughout this book, I didnâ€™t feel like it went over my head too much that I felt annoyed reading it - I actually quite enjoyed learning much about the realm of space, engineering and physics. I also liked the set up of this book, following Markâ€™s experience on Mars through his own first-person journal entries.
.
If you want a face-paced story of survival full of drama, problem-solving & a sarcastic botanist astronaut (who becomes the first to cultivate Mars soil by growing potatoesğŸ¥”), you will fall in love with Andy Weirâ€™s â€œThe Martianâ€ as I have. Now, time to watch the movie adaptation!

The Stand ğŸ¦  Stephen King
.
Something goes horribly wrong at a biological testing facility & employees hurriedly rush to lockdown the entire area but one guard gets out unknowingly carrying the super-flu virus originally intended for warfare purposes. â€œCaptain Tripsâ€ as the sickness comes to be known is an antigen-shifting virus and it is lethal to 99% of people.
.
In a horrifically short amount of time, billions of people are dead, drowned in their own snot & the few immune survivors are stuck with a new problem: where do they go from here?
.
Along with the billion of decaying bodies, miles of car pileups and no electrical power, the surviving individuals are having dreams & nightmares of what the future holds. Some see the 108 year-old black woman who calls herself Mother Abigail and believes her final mission is to carry out Godâ€™s plan. She calls people to start a commune in Boulder Colorado and live peacefully.
.
In their nightmares, the one they call â€œThe Dark Manâ€ visits & asks them to come worship him in the new Las Vegas where sin and lust and greed can flourish. The Dark Man embodies evil and thrives on violence and death & wants to see the world burn. Anyone who does not join him will perish. In the end, only the survivors can decide the ultimate fate of humanity. 
.
Okay, this books was INCREDIBLE & like, real-life scary. But how does one even begin to summarize a 1,153 page book?! Itâ€™s very hard. The things I enjoyed most about this book were the character development, the detail & the ultimate battle between good and evil. This book makes you THINK and feel paranoid about how the world really would play out if 99% of us were wiped out.
.
To summarize my thoughts? Basically - read this book. Itâ€™s often called Kingâ€™s best work for a reason. It will make you laugh, cry, gasp and cringe. It shows you the very worst and the very best of humanity & to conquer evil, sometimes good must be sacrificed. One of the scariest thoughts I had is what side would most people choose if this happened today? Iâ€™d like to think good would win out, but, thatâ€™s also not guaranteed. 
.
ALL THE STARS for this door-stopper of a book â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸

THE HOME STRETCH â˜•ï¸ #coffeeandcurrentlyreading 
.
I hit page 931 in The Stand by Stephen King today & that means I am on the final part of this 1,153 page beast of a book. I donâ€™t believe King has ever had a thought that is less than 500 pages ğŸ˜‚
.
This is the first time Iâ€™ve tackled a novel over 1,000 pages & I was very intimidated at the start. But, I shouldâ€™ve known Iâ€™d fall head first [down the rabbit hole, if you may] into this story. Iâ€™ve loved all my past experiences reading King & Iâ€™ve heard from many that this is his best work. I have definitely been blown away.
.
I have mixed feelings about being so close to the ending! I really donâ€™t want this story to end, yet I am very anxious to find out what happens. Looking forward to reviewing this book soon!
.
Also, to all my book friends out there that have been wanting to tackle a 1000+ page book, GO FOR IT! You may be pleasantly surprised how quick it reads & it will definitely give you a sense of accomplishment [& an arm workout!] ğŸ’ªğŸ¼ğŸ“š

A Series of Unfortunate Events ğŸ‘ Lemony Snicket
.
Oh how I thoroughly enjoyed my reread of the Vastly Frightful Despicable story of the Baudelaire orphans, a story I havenâ€™t revisited since my elementary school days (thank heavens my school experience was nothing like the Baudelaireâ€™s at Prufrock Prep.)
.
For those who know nothing of this Very Foul Disturbing narrative, It begins with the terrible fire that destroys the mansion & parents of Violet, Klaus & Sunny Baudelaire. Mr. Poe, a banker who always has a persistent cough, is in charge of their affairs and places them in the care of their [extremely] distant relative Count Olaf. The Count is a Villanous, Foul, Dishonest man (who believes himself to be a handsome/talented actor which is just not the case) whose main motive is scheming to get his hands on the Baudelaire fortune.
.
Throughout the books, the orphans travel from relative to relative only to find that misfortune and despair follow them everywhere & Count Olaf is always a step behind them making their lives more & more dangerous & miserable with each scheme. Only with Violetâ€™s keen inventing mind, Klausâ€™s wonderful research talents & Sunnyâ€™s dental/cooking abilities are the children able to [barely] escape Olafâ€™s clutches each time. 
.
As the list of unfortunate events, murdered guardians, mysteries surrounding V.F.D. - a secret organization that the Baudelaire parents were part of - & sinister tattoos of eyes on ankles, which may stand for something noble or treacherous, the Baudelaire orphans wonder if their lives will ever be cheerful again. 
.
This series will take you, the reader, into the stormy waters of Lake Lachrymose with man-eating leeches, into a horrible school where the vice principle does not know how to play the violin but insists on doing so anyways, down a pitch black elevator shaft to rescue triplets, into a run-down carnival with starved lions, through the tallest mountains & the deepest caves of the sea - & if you decide to continue reading, which the author will advise you against - good luck, my Valued Fortunate Distingushed friend.

.

Finishing out 2020 with 78 books! ğŸ“š
.
Despite all the negatives 2020 brought with it, this year also allowed for more family time, learning to not take things for granted & [for me] it was the year I brought reading for fun back into my life & discovered the amazing bookstagram community! â¤ï¸ I cannot wait to continue to read, chat about books & make new friends here in 2021! 
.

At the beginning of 2020, I promised myself I would read more classics/modern classics & reread ones that I didnâ€™t appreciate in school. This reading challenge was made much easier by my â€œ100 Epic Reads of a Lifetimeâ€ scratch off novelogue by @bnthr_dntht! I made it to 30/100 this year! 
.
I am a very type-A person & being able to scratch-off after reading a book was both motivating & extremely satisfying for me! Plus, I love the simple yet classic design of the poster - looks great hanging next to any bookshelf! ğŸ“šğŸ¥°

People Like Her ğŸ“± Ellery Lloyd (#3 in my water trilogy)
.
Emmy never intended to become an Instagram influencer, but after finding out she was pregnant & her dream of being in charge of a fashion magazine becoming a thing of the past, Emmy searched for a way to build a career around being a mom. Thus, Mamabare was born.
.
Fast-forward a few years & add 1 million + followers & adoring fans, Mamabare is the platform Emmy connects to the millions of mums seeking solace in someone who gets what theyâ€™re going through. Synopsis: 
In a nightmarish, futuristic England where criminals take over after dark we follow the story of our narrator, Alex and his droogs (friends) while they spend their nights getting high before robbing & beating men and raping women. Nothing seems to be able to touch them, until a home-raid goes terribly wrong & Alex gets caught and sent to prison. In an effort to shorten his sentence, Alex opts for a new experimental treatment that claims to â€œcureâ€ criminals. However, the controversy over this treatment is that it strips the receiver of choice between the good and the bad. For Alex, returning to society a â€œcuredâ€ man may actually mean becoming a helpless victim himself. â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”
At first, I almost didnâ€™t continue reading this book because it utilizes â€™nadsat languageâ€™ a kind of Russian slangâ€”I spent the first few chapters frustratingly looking up the meanings to words. But after awhile you start to learn what the words mean, and even come to like it.
â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”
I thought this book was going to be another dystopian novel all about violence, and while there is horrifying violence depicted, the book does not glorify violence nor do I think that is what the book is meant to be about. Rather, it explores the question of good & evil and what it means to be human. Is it better to choose to do bad than to be scientifically conditioned to be good, being stripped of having the ability to choose for yourself? â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”
I recommend you find the edition that includes the final chapter. But read the story first as if it didnâ€™t include the final chapter. It is amazing how the outlook of the story changes when you experience both of these different â€œendings.â€ Overall, if youâ€™re going to read A Clockwork Orange, pour yourself a glass of wine in advance, O my brothers.

Nothing would make Mrs. Bennett happier than seeing all of her daughters married to wealthy men. At the arrival of Mr. Bingley, a rich bachelor who has just arrived in the neighborhood, the eldest daughter, Jane, makes a fast connection. The second eldest daughter, Elizabeth, has quite the opposite connection with Mr. Bingleyâ€™s [even wealthier] friend, Mr. Darcy whom she believes to be vain, haughty and conceited. As the story unfolds, Elizabeth finds that oftentimes, first impressions arenâ€™t what they seem. â €

This was my first experience reading anything by Jane Austen and I am absolutely enchanted by her. This book highlights how different the prospect of marriage was for women in the late 1700s-early 1800s and the importance of a woman having some wealth to be gained upon being married. Austen depicts well the entitlement of the wealthy and the â€œrightâ€ they felt they had to control the actions of lesser class individuals. There were many times my mouth hung open reading paragraphs of insults written in such elegant prose â€” Elizabeth always holds her own though, staying fiercely loyal to who she is, yet, humble enough to admit when she has made mistakes. â €
â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

In Edwardian Suffolk, a manor house stands alone in a lost corner of the Fens: a glinting wilderness of water whose whispering reeds guard ancient secrets. Maud is a lonely child growing up without a mother, ruled by her repressive father. When he finds a painted medieval devil in a graveyard, unhallowed forces are awakened. Maud's battle has begun. She must survive a world haunted by witchcraft, the age-old legends of her beloved fen - and the even more nightmarish demons of her father's past. 
â£
Spanning five centuries, Wakenhyrst is a darkly gothic thriller about murderous obsession and one girl's longing to fly free..
â£
From the start I found this book really intriguing.Â  The Suffolk Fens provide a brooding backdrop to the story, with hints of the supernatural.
Â 
While much of the novel is set in the Edwardian era, the tale of female oppression is timely, and I thought it couldâ€™ve easily been set 200 year prior.
Â 
I found Maud to be an unlikely feminist heroine who, while she had her own dark secrets, I was rooting for her the entire story.Â 
â£
Her fatherâ€™s behaviour and attitude towards women was appalling, he was suppressive and controlling and I wanting to scream when reading his journal entries. Â 
Â 
Paver has wonderfully researched this era and setting to create a magnificent piece of fiction.
Â 
I only have one bone to pick, and without giving too much away â€“ I just want to know more about THAT twist.Â  Otherwise, I highly recommend this gothic novel!

What if everyone you loved was suddenly taken away? Five siblings struggle to stay together as the tides of war threaten to tear them apart.
â£
When Germany invades and occupies France in the Second World War, the five Laskowski children lose everything: their home, their Jewish community and most devastatingly their parents who are abducted in the night. 
â£
There is no safe place left for them to evade the Nazis, but they cling together, never certain when the authorities will come for what is left of them.
â£
Inspired by the poignant, true story of the authorâ€™s mother, this moving historical novel conveys the hardship, the uncertainty and the impossible choices the Laskowski children were forced to make to survive the horrors of the Holocaust.

There isnâ€™t much I could put down in words about this book. Written with lyrical prose and such pounding emotion ğ—§ğ—µğ—² ğ—¬ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¦ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜€ is a truely heartbreaking story. I read it in one sitting and would recommend to all historical fiction readers.

â €â €

Driving home one night, stuck behind a rusty old car, Gabe sees a little girlâ€™s face appear in its rear window. She mouths one word:Â Daddy. Itâ€™s his five-year-old daughter, Izzy. He never sees her again. 
Three years later, Gabe spends his days and nights traveling up and down the highway, searching for the car that took his daughter, refusing to give up hope, even though most people believe sheâ€™s dead. â€œThroughout the year, it seemed, there were events designed to remind the lonely that they were indeed lonely.â€ Fran and her daughter, Alice, also put in a lot of miles on the road. Not searching. Running. Because Fran knows what really happened to Gabeâ€™s daughter.Â She knows who is responsible. And she knows what they will do if they ever catch up to her and Alice.

Thriller and horror/supernatural novels are NOT my cup of tea. I find myself thinking â€œWTF?!â€ throughout the first quarter of The Other People. Initially confused by how all the characters were intertwined with each other (though I think this is perhaps intentional?), the connecting elements started to come together.

The Other People is really well written, I can definitely see why the author has been compared to Stephen King, and while I didnâ€™t love this novel - I couldnâ€™t put it down because I just had to know what happened!! During the 1980s, Jack Kelly was a celebrity broadcaster and successful novelist. His life in the public eye allowed him a privileged position which few experienced, with access to select places and an army of adoring fans. Several decades later, Jack receives a phone call from his secretary. The urgency in her voice stops him in his tracks. A story about Jack has emerged on social media and gone viral. It details his relationship with a young woman, Marian Davies, thirty years previously. The last thing Jack needs is scandal, especially when he's about to embark on an important new career move. As he looks back over the decades since he last saw Marian, to a time before social media when he controlled the narrative, one question remains: why has Marian reappeared?

âœ¨ PEOPLE LIKE US âœ¨ by Louise Fein 4/5 Stars â­ï¸ â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸
â€¢
â€¢
Hetty Henrich is a perfect German child. Her father is an SS officer, her brother in the Hitler Youth, training to become a fighter pilot, herself a member of the BDM. She believes resolutely in her country, and the man who runs it.
â€¢
â€¢
â€¢
Until Walter changes everything. Blonde-haired, blue-eyed Walter. The boy who saved her life. A Jew.
As Hetty falls deeply in love with a man who is everything sheâ€™s been taught to hate, she will have to risk everything to save him, even if it means sacrificing herself.
â€¢
â€¢
â€¢
Wow. My heart ached after reading this. From the outset you understand that, probably like so many children of the Reich, Hetty doesnâ€™t fully comprehend what is going on in the world around her - or why. There is a vague innocence about it all. That the physical traits between an Ayran child and a Jewish child are difficult to tell. But soon Hetty starts to discover that Walter â€œoozes othernessâ€, that looks are deceiving, blood and breeding never lie. 
She decides that Walter is worth the risk. â€¢
â€¢
â€¢
There are themes are sexuality throughout, the different social expectations of genders. Why can a boy do this, but a girl canâ€™t? â€¢
â€¢
â€¢
The author has done an amazing job of describing that not all Germans agreed with the racial hatred regime forced upon them. Hetty begins to learn of the hardships and restrictions placed on Jewish people. Her mind alters and her love for Walter grows. She starts to stand up for her own beliefs, while hiding a number of secrets too.
â€¢
â€¢
â€¢
Stories from this time are rarely written from the â€œNaziâ€ point of view, it was heartbreakingly refreshing.
â€¢
â€¢
â€¢
â€œThere are two sides, or more perhaps, to every thought. Every action. We only ever want to see one.â€

.

#mythoughts :

I actually laughed at much of this book and it was exactly what I needed. Thereâ€™s such a great mix of humor and real issues though. Being the same age as the main character made me completely invested in her story.

Bells Walker is 42, finds out sheâ€™s pregnant after a failed IUD, and then that her family is moving to a small town called Pigkill. 
She really tries to make the best of things, sheâ€™s wanted a bigger place for her growing family, she wants her husband to feel important in the university arena after trying for tenure..... but when she sees the dilapidated home, the savage mom groups, kombucha everywhere (!!!), sheâ€™s had enough. 
She starts an anonymous blog about the people in her small town and calls herself the County Dutchess. Itâ€™s takes off like wildfire and Bells finally feels important for a change. Sheâ€™s always sacrificing her wants and needs and boy it feels good to be writing. 
But if comes at a cost. Someone figures out the person behind the blog and all hell breaks loose. 
Personally I wanted her husband to be less self-centered and less selfish, but I think thatâ€™s part of the ultimate point. His mother obviously dotes on him, and his brothers success makes him a bit insecure. 

I find the observations Bells makes hilarious, I think overuse of the word millennial is intentional. The end is so sweet, and there is a moment with her teenage son that absolutely made me tear up. I really loved this book, highly recommend if you want a laugh with a side of substance. And maybe to find out what the hell a Bisnut is.
.

The remarkable woman at heart of the smash New York Times bestseller and Oscar-winning film Hidden Figures tells the full story of her life, including what it took to work at NASA, help land the first man on the moon, and live through a century of turmoil and change.

In this memoir, Katherine shares her personal journey from child prodigy in the Allegheny Mountains of West Virginia to NASA human computer. In her life after retirement, she served  as a beacon of light for her family and community alike.  Her story is centered around the basic tenets of her lifeâ€”no one is better than you, education is paramount, and asking questions can break barriers. The memoir captures the many facets of this unique woman: the curious â€œdaddyâ€™s girl,â€ pioneering professional, and sage elder. 

This multidimensional portrait is also the record of a century of racial history that reveals the influential role educators at segregated schools and Historically Black Colleges and Universities played in nurturing the dreams of trailblazers like Katherine. The author pays homage to her mentorâ€”the African American professor who inspired her to become a research mathematician despite having his own dream crushed by racism.

âœ¨CRYING IN H MARTâœ¨ 
By: Michelle Zauner 

I am not the hugest fan of memoirs, but this one is so unique. It combines family, food, grief, and love. 

Excerpt:

Every dish I cooked exhumed a memory. Every scent and taste brought me back for a moment to an unravaged home. Knife-cut noodles in chicken broth took me back to lunch at Myeongdong Gyoja after an afternoon of shopping, the line so long it filled a flight of stairs, extended out the door, and wrapped around the building. The kalguksu so dense from the rich beef stock and starchy noodles it was nearly gelatinous. My mother ordering more and more refills of their famously garlic- heavy kimchi. My aunt scolding her for blowing her nose in public. 
 
Crispy Korean fried chicken conjured bachelor nights with Eunmi. Licking oil from our fingers as we chewed on the crispy skin, cleansing our palates with draft beer and white radish cubes as she helped me with my Korean homework. Black- bean noodles summoned Halmoni slurping jjajangmyeon takeout, huddled around a low table in the living room with the rest of my Korean family. 
__________________________________________________
.
Thank you so much to @booksparks @aaknopf for my gifted book and for including it in the #SRC2021 lineup. Itâ€™s out now and I highly recommend you grab it. 
.
.
Is food part of how you access your memories? It is for me. Sometimes I close my eyes and see myself in the kitchen with my grandma, chopping celery for the Thanksgiving stuffing. 
.
.
.

They are at odds with a school budget plan involving throwing money towards sports or science. In their ten-year friendship theyâ€™ve never fought or kept anything from each other. Mimi whoâ€™s son Rowan is a football player, wants the budget to go that way, Grace, whoâ€™s son Carter is more interested in academia wants money thrown to that arena. Both mothers are interested in getting their sons into the best colleges they can. With differing abilities, the budget could help one or the other boy.
However, when Carter is brutally injured in an accident at Mimiâ€™s house, Grace and Mimi may never be the same.
.
.
I must admit, I liked Mimiâ€™s character more than Graceâ€™s, although I completely understood through her backstory where her issues stemmed from. I love that Mimi, even through her own pain and strife, continued to pray and wish goodwill towards Carter. Thatâ€™s a real friend, one who loves your child even when there are problems in your friendship. Which brings me the other part I loved and that is the importance of female friendship in the book. You need those ladies who are always there for you, through thick and thin. Especially as a momma. 
I really enjoyed this book, thank you to @booksparks , @amazonpublishing & @writerjamiebeck for my review copy.

Iâ€™ve long had an intense interest in the AIDS epidemic. I started watching and reading everything I could in the way of statistics, personal stories, sociological impact.

.

.
. 
Brian Malloy has written a raw look at grief in 28-year-old Kevin Doyle. Kevin goes to a lot of funerals, even describing â€œorthodoxâ€ and â€œconservativeâ€ AIDS funerals. The former being one in which no one mentions the partner of the dead and pretends they werenâ€™t gay. The latter in which the partner situs with the family as a roommate or best friend. 
.
.
.
.
Francesco has been gone for three years now and Kevin is still holding on to the man and the memories that were the best of his life. We get Francescoâ€™s voice through Kevinâ€™s imagination, he still talks to him as though heâ€™s there. He still lives in their apartment, unwilling to move on. 
When he finally realizes itâ€™s time to start trying to live again, he moves back home to Minnesota. 
.

.
.
I still have to read the end, but this book is a truthful study in grief and loss and love. Iâ€™m drawn to reading about those processes because I have a difficult time with them. 
I think if you liked â€œThe Great Believersâ€ youâ€™d like this one.

â˜•ï¸ğŸ“– Book Review â˜•ï¸ğŸ“–
Thank you so much to @suzyapprovedbooktours , @patriciawalshchadwick & @posthillpress for my spot on the #LittleSister book tour. 
.
.
My thoughts:
Patricia grew up in a Catholic cult. Her memories support the cult getting more and more exclusive as cults do. She recounts how Father Leonard Feeny went from entertaining such Catholics as JFK, to falling from grace and being excommunicated from the Catholic Church. A devout group of followers, including Patriciaâ€™s parents, followed him into â€œorthodox Catholicismâ€, a group not recognized and in fact condemned by the Catholic Church. Their mantra was â€œNo Salvation Outside the Catholic Church. 
Marriages were performed in secret, they built a compound the called The Center, with a red fence around it, and eventually husbands, wives, and children didnt cohabitate. The members were not allowed any information from outside their bubble. So when a 17 year old Patricia Walsh was kicked out of the faith and itâ€™s walls, she was terrified. With absolutely nothing to go on, she had to build a life from nothing. And with determination, she did extremely well. 
What was interesting to me is how she perceived the devolution of the group as a child. How she noticed, slowly, people were robbed of their autonomy. They were made to shed their clothing in exchange for a black uniform of sorts. Father Feeney changed their names, separated husbands, wives, and their children. Father Feeney let his minion, Catherine Clarke wield an ugly fist of power and destruction. 
What really impressed me about this book is the power of forgiveness and that Patricia was able to fully embrace it and not live in perpetual anger. I have to give this 5 stars because it is a great story and quite fascinating as well. I highly recommend to those of you who love a good memoir and maybe who have an interest in the psychology of cults like I do. 
.
.
.
.
.

From Cicely herself about the book:
"Just As I Am is my truth. It is me, plain and unvarnished, with the glitter and garland set aside. The UK develops an initiative to store its security secrets within the minds of five humans. Humans canâ€™t be hacked, they can be trained to be soldiers for the government. What could go wrong? Well humans are fallible and .... human. Fellow Marrs fans will be happy to know that plot elements from both â€œThe Passengersâ€ and â€œThe Oneâ€ make it into this book, weaving it into a fantastic semi-extension. But make no mistake, this is a stand-alone with the twists, turns and ultimate horror that youâ€™d expect.

My thoughts:
I really liked this dark, atmospheric domestic thriller. 
Set in small-town upstate New York, everything played out like a movie while I read. Maybe thatâ€™s how good Pashley is at vivid description. 
We get two points of view, that of seasoned detective Kateri Fisher, and that of Shannon Jenkins, a drop out teen who had to grow up far too quickly.
Since this is the second in a series, we get a few references to Kateriâ€™s past which I really enjoyed. I love seeing a well faceted, fleshed out character. 
Shannonâ€™s parts are heartbreaking. Heâ€™s almost metaphorically cut off at the legs before he even has a chance in the world. An addicted mother, a secret sister, and bills to pay. He meets a handsome stranger in the diner he works for and things finally seem to be turning around for him financially. 
Until the day blood is found everywhere in the home he shares with his mother , and his secret sister is found hiding in a closet. The obvious culprit to everyone seems to be Shannon, but Kateri has a nose for depravity and she has a feeling they need to look further than the scared teenager in front of them.
I really love how this one wrapped up and Iâ€™m hoping itâ€™s not the last we see of Kateri.

Iâ€™m also fond of a slow burn thriller.

What I donâ€™t like are wooden, flat characters. This book wasnâ€™t that at all. It was uncomfortable in is rawness and honesty in fact. 
I disagreed that all 12 year old boys want to find a dead body, until I remembered there is an entire movie dedicated to that notion (Stand by Me, a story by Stephen King before it was a movie). 
Maybe the only beef I had with this book is that I wanted more. I donâ€™t know why but I could have kept reading about this group of ragtag kids turned awkward adults. Because I loved this one so much, i just ordered â€œThe Other Peopleâ€.

âœ¨Book Reviewâœ¨
Thank you to @suzyapprovedbooktours & @joannafitzpatrick.author for my copy of #KatherineMansfield to review.
.
.
Prior to getting this book, I had only a cursory body of knowledge regarding Katherine. I knew she was a contemporary of Virginia Woolf and I had read I tiny bit of her writing. 
What the author did with this story is take what we know and give it life. She gave Katherine a voice, and a personality with extensive research. 
.
. 
I loved her spunk, and her bohemian lifestyle. I mostly resonated with her medical battle. She was determined to beat tuberculosis, going to several different doctors, and trying several experimental treatments, even slightly defying her husbandâ€™s opinions. 
It is the mark of a fighter, to never give up. It saddened me that she so desperately wanted to join her friends in simple things outdoors. My heart broke for her a lot. Knowing that she only lived to be 34 was gut wrenching as I read. 
I am definitely going to read more of her writing. She was so talented. 
4â­ï¸
.
.
.
.

Synopsis:

Robert Valmer moves from Rome to Beverly Hills in 2015, where against his better judgment, he falls for Alexis Roth, PhD, psychologist to the stars. But Alexis wants to know everything. Start from the beginning, she says. The beginning? Can he really tell her about how he fled France during the French Revolution in 1789 or about Italy during World War II? If he tells her even a little, will she think of him as a liar or a freak rather than a lover?

He tries to deflect her probes, pleading shyness, but she knows that reticence is often the veil behind which secrecy lurks. His practice of stonewalling only further ignites her burning curiosity.

As the pressure for honesty mounts, he does what heâ€™s always doneâ€”flee. But Alexis is not a lover to be easily dismissed. She follows him to Europe, determined to track him down for an explanation. Where can she start when her quarry doesnâ€™t want to be found? Each clue she uncovers leads her deeper into intrigue.

.
.
.
If youâ€™re down for a good mystery, with some time travel, this is your book.

1969: the height of counterculture and the year universities would seek to curb the unruly spectacle of student protest; the winter that Harvard University would begin the tumultuous process of merging with Radcliffe, its all-female sister school; and the year that Jane Britton, an ambitious 23-year-old graduate student in Harvard's Anthropology Department and daughter of Radcliffe Vice President J. Boyd Britton, would be found bludgeoned to death in her Cambridge, Massachusetts apartment.

SYNOPSIS: 

From the outside, everyone might think Fern and Rose are as close as twin sisters can be: Rose is the responsible one, with a home and a husband and a fierce desire to become a mother. Fern is the quirky one, the free spirit, the librarian who avoids social interaction and whom the world might just describe as truly odd. But the sisters are devoted to one another and Rose has always been Fern's protector from the time they were small. 

Fern needed protecting because their mother was a true sociopath who hid her true nature from the world, and only Rose could see it. Fern always saw the good in everyone. Years ago, Fern did something very, very bad. And Rose has never told a soul. When Fern decides to help her sister achieve her heart's desire of having a baby, Rose realizes with growing horror that Fern might make choices that can only have a terrible outcome. What Rose doesn't realize is that Fern is growing more and more aware of the secrets Rose, herself, is keeping. And that their mother might have the last word after all.

SYNOPSIS:
When Bianca appears late one night at her brother's house in Santa Ana, she is barely conscious, though not alone. Jubilee, wrapped in a fuzzy pink romper, is buckled into a car seat. Jubilee, who Bianca feeds and clothes and bathes and loves. Jubilee, who Bianca could not leave behind. Jubilee, a doll in her arms.
Told in alternating points of view, Jubilee reveals both the haunting power of our lived experiences and the surreal possibility of the present to heal the past.

The first thread, "Before Jubilee," follows Bianca in her girlhood home on the Mexicali border as she struggles with her high school sweetheart, Gabe, and a secret they've shared since she was fifteen.
The second thread, "With Jubilee," is told from the point of view of her new love, Joshua, who along with Bianca's family helps her cope with a mysterious trauma by accepting Jubilee as part of the family. As Joshua's love for Bianca grows, he fears that Jubilee has the power to tear his tiny family apart.
Alternating chapters give readers a unique perspective on Bianca's present and on her relationship with Jubilee as her past life with Gabe comes to a catastrophic end.

@lakeunionauthors publisher

.

My thoughts:
I completely loved this book from beginning to end. Possibly because I identified with so much of it, but it touches on such relatable topics, I feel like anyone might. 
Liz loses her husband Thomas, a pastor, within the first few pages. I like that it jumps right into her journey. Right during the loathsome knitting circle that Liz leads and canâ€™t stand. Sheâ€™s a pastors wife, but we find out that her choices were never simple. And that sheâ€™s dying to break free.
When Thomas dies, itâ€™s her chance. 
She joins a theater group through her friend (eventually bestie Val), meets her kinda crush Lance there, and starts to really live. 
She also realizes just how much under Thomasâ€™s thumb she was. Which leads her to realize that their grown daughter, Abigail, was completely controlled by Thomas as well. 
Abigail tries to control Liz but Liz is never going back. 
And then gasp, a pregnancy out of wedlock.

Mmkay, I hated Thomas for the entire book, and didnâ€™t like Abigail until the last few pages. I think I audibly uttered â€œback the fuck offâ€ at least once.

But I have met women like Liz , especially in the church (certainly not trying to put down organized religion here) , so I recognized her self doubt and the realizations she had. 
There was such immense beauty in her journey, I cried. I was rooting for her and felt for her. I think itâ€™s been a while since I connected to a character this much. 
I couldnâ€™t put this down, and loved the entire story. 5â­ï¸

So the book synopsis: 

The most common triggers for homicide are fear, rage, revenge, money, lust, and, more rarely, sheer madness. This isnâ€™t an exact science, of course. Any given murder can have multiple triggers. Sex and revenge seem to be common partners in crime. Rage, money, and revenge make for a dangerous trifecta of triggers, as well.

This book offers my memories of homicide cases that I investigated or oversaw. In each case, I examine the trigger that led to death. I chose this theme for the book because even though the why of a murder case may not be critical in an investigation, it can sometimes lead us to the killer.

And even if we solve a case without knowing the trigger, the why still intrigues us, disrupting our dreams and lingering in our minds, perhaps because each of us fears the demons that lie within our own psycheâ€”the triggers waiting to be pulled.

SYNOPSIS:

Agatha Arch's life shatters when she discovers her husband in their backyard shed, in flagrante delicto, giving the local dog walker some heavy petting. Suddenly, Agatha finds herself face to face with everything that frightens her...and that's a loooooong list.

Agatha keeps those she loves close. Everyone else, she keeps as far away as possible. So she's a mystery to nearly everyone in her New England town. To her husband, she's a saucy, no-B.S. writer. To her Facebook Moms group, she's a provocateur. To her neighbor, she's a standoffish pain in the butt. To her sons, she's chocolate pudding with marshmallows. And to her shrink, she's a bundle of nerves on the brink of a cataclysmic implosion.

Defying her abundant assortment of anxieties, Agatha dons her "spy pants"--a pair of khakis whose many pockets she crams with binoculars, fishing line, scissors, flashlight, a Leatherman Super Tool 300 EOD, candy, and other espionage essentials--and sets out to spy on her husband and the dog walker. Along the way, she finds another intriguing target to follow: a mysterious young woman who's panhandling on the busiest street in town.

It's all a bit much for timorous Agatha. But with the help of her Bear Grylls bobblehead, a trio of goats, and a dog named Balderdash, Agatha may just find the courage to build a better life.

SYNOPSIS:

Margot Lee's mother, Mina, isn't returning her calls. It's a mystery to twenty-six-year-old Margot, until she visits her childhood apartment in Koreatown, LA, and finds that her mother has suspiciously died. The discovery sends Margot digging through the past, unraveling the tenuous invisible strings that held together her single mother's life as a Korean War orphan and an undocumented immigrant, only to realize how little she truly knew about her mother.

Interwoven with Margot's present-day search is Mina's story of her first year in Los Angeles as she navigates the promises and perils of the American myth of reinvention. While she's barely earning a living by stocking shelves at a Korean grocery store, the last thing Mina ever expects is to fall in love. But that love story sets in motion a series of events that have consequences for years to come, leading up to the truth of what happened the night of her death.

Told through the intimate lens of a mother and daughter who have struggled all their lives to understand each other, The Last Story of Mina Lee is a powerful and exquisitely woven debut novel that explores identity, family, secrets, and what it truly means to belong.

SYNOPSIS:
Four young children caught between love and hateâ€”hostages to the cruelty of revenge. A deceitful American father and a naÃ¯ve decision by a Filipino mother transformed their lives forever. 
Valorie, Veronica, Vance, and Vincentâ€™s perfect world turned into a nightmare one hot afternoon in 1959 in Cebu, Philippines. What was to be a quick lunch with their father turned into a flight to America, where four dreadfully long years of running from state to state, hiding, and vanishing into the night followed. Kidnapped from the only world they knew, confusion quickly set in. At nine, Valorie, the eldest, liked seeing their father after his absence for over a year. Vance, a timid six-year-old, went along with whatever Valorie did. Vincent, the baby at three, cried for his mother while clinging to Veronica for comfort. Veronica, eight, was the only one who was truly panicked by what was happening around themâ€”and she recognized instantly that she and her siblings would have to stick together in order to survive. In that moment, her childhood ended and the warrior within her emerged. 

Moving from state to state and school to school, avoiding the law, looking over their shoulders at every turn, the four Slaughter children found themselves fighting not only the heartbreak of separation from their loving mother but also poverty, discrimination, and abuse. Their only weapons were their deep love for one another and an unwavering determination to survive the trials they facedâ€”and find their way back to their mother. 
â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

â€œThe First To Lieâ€by Hank Phillippi Ryan 
Publishes on 8/4/2020 by @forgereads 
.
.

Pay attention when you read this! There are many characters, multiple POV switching, extremely detail oriented. I can only imagine that comes from Hanks background in investigative reporting.
There are so many layered lies interwoven through each other, as the story unfolded my shoulders let go of their tension. Because I was on the edge of my seat reading this, trying to guess where it was headed. 
Thereâ€™s also the present and the past to contend with in dissecting this story, and it all hinges on taking down Pharminex, a drug company complicit in death and sterility for women. 
Monifan is supposed to be a miracle drug for women suffering from fertility issues, the use of it for such is off label though. For many women it proves to be a nightmare, robbing them of the chance to ever have children. 
The Vanderwald family owns Pharminex and isnâ€™t going to let their fortune go so easily. 

Thereâ€™s a reporter, her assistant, a lawyer, a woman posing as a pharmacy rep.... but which one is the liar?

.
.
Last night I was so exhausted and just responding to my son on autopilot mode.
He asks, â€œwhatâ€™s wrong momma?â€
I say, â€œMommaâ€™s just a little sadâ€.
.
.

.
.
â€œNo reason baby, sometimes you just get sad.â€
.
.
â€œIs it because of Aunt Margie?â€
.
.
Wow guys, kids really do pay attention to everything. The previous night he had a memory of my aunts home. Which led to a conversation about death and cancer. And he picked up on the fact that his Auntie Phia has cancer. The fear in his eyes was palpable. I held my breath before speaking. 
.
.
These are such difficult conversations but I donâ€™t believe in shielding my son from everything, nor can I. We are realizing that he picks up even on our unspoken moments. So Iâ€™m honest with him. Sensitive, but honest.

Do your best and give yourself grace. That is my hope for you all my friends.

This is the sequel to #matchmakingforbeginners but I found that it can absolutely be read as a stand alone. Though the first book is delightful I hear. 
This story really is magical, quite literally! Marnie is a matchmaker and sees sparkles around her matches. If that sounds not believable, itâ€™s written in the most sincere way, there isnâ€™t anything campy about it. 
Marnie has a big question to ask her longtime boyfriend Patrick. 
She wants them to have a baby.
Patrick, for reasons of his own, isnâ€™t on the same page. 
In comes Fritzie......
Fritzie is the product of a one night stand from Patrickâ€™s past. Her mother basically leaves her at the doorstep. 
Marnie is sweetness and love incarnate because she takes this little girl as if sheâ€™s her own. 

Patrick isnâ€™t so sure about any of it. I began to get really annoyed with him, I didnâ€™t think he deserved Marnie. 
And at a point, she decides the same. 
I would rather not give too much away, because this is a completely charming story. But what I will say is that I had tears in my eyes and then went into the ugly cry at the end. 
On a personal note: I absolutely love the way @maddiedaws puts adoption in such a beautiful light. I have fertility issues and so do my sisters. Adoption is an amazing thing and I love when itâ€™s handled so wonderfully in literature.

SYNOPSIS:

LONDON: On a fine avenue of grand houses, big cars and electronic gates, lies a neglected urban wasteland

It is nearly midnight, and very cold. Yet in this dark place of long grass and tall trees where cats hunt and foxes shriek, a girl is waiting... When Saffyre Maddox was ten something terrible happened and she's carried the pain of it around with her ever since. The man who she thought was going to heal her didn't, and now she hides from him, invisible in the shadows, learning his secrets; secrets she could use to blow his safe, cosy world apart.

Owen Pick is invisible too. He's thirty-three years old and he's never had a girlfriend, he's never even had a friend. Nobody sees him. Nobody cares about him.

But when Saffyre Maddox disappears from opposite his house on Valentine's night, suddenly the whole world is looking at him. Accusing him. Holding him responsible.

Because he's just the type, isn't he? A bit creepy?

INVISIBLE GIRL: A story of secrets and injustices, and of how we look in the wrong places for the bad people while the real predators walk among us in plain sight. â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

SYNOPSIS:

Amanda is a new mother, and she is breaking. After a fight with her partner, she puts the baby in the car and drives from Queens to her hometown in rural Ohio, where she shows up unannounced on the doorstep of her estranged childhood best friend. Amanda thought that she had left Carrie firmly in the past. After their friendship ended, their lives diverged radically: Carrie had a baby the summer after high school, became a successful tattoo artist, and never escaped Ohio s conservative grid of close-cut grass. But the trauma of childbirth and shock of motherhood compel Amanda to go back to the beginning and to trace the tangled roots of friendship and family in her own life.

Compelling and engaging, Everything Here Is under Control is a raw, honest, occasionally hilarious portrait of the complexity, conflicting emotions, and physical trauma of both modern motherhood and the intense, intimate friendships that women forge in their youth.

I canâ€™t imagine what the mother of a Columbine shooter would go through. As parents we feel and know that we will love our children through anything and everything. Even Ted Bundyâ€™s mother loved him, though she was tormented by what he was.
And that I imagine is sheer torture. 
We hope to raise decent human beings. We know they wonâ€™t be perfect, but we expect that what at least some of what we instill will stick.
In the case of a parent who has a child with damaging, violent pathology, Iâ€™d assume there is so much guilt. 
I feel guilt on a daily basis. 
Am I doing enough, too much, making good memories more than bad. Will he grow up strong but empathetic, kind but wise.
The meanderings of the typical mom brain.
But if he were to do something devastating, something that affected many people.... what would that mean, how would I feel about this life that I put out into the world.... .
.
Sue Klebold wrote a powerful memoir, very well structured. The chapters are divided into parts one and two, with each individual chapter touching on a specific things, titles like â€œBoyhoodâ€ and â€œThe End of Denialâ€.
.
.
.
I have already started reading and I feel like Iâ€™ll cry at least once. Anyone who knows me knows that the most important thing in my life has been the near impossible miracle of becoming a momma. I was told it wasnâ€™t to be. So I might be a little more sentimental than some parents! .
.
.
.

.
.

.
.

BOOK REVIEW: â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ â€œI CANâ€™T STAND CONTEMPORARY ROMANCE!!â€ I scream in my head as I feverishly devour this book.
What I donâ€™t like about romance as a genre is the fluff factor. I can read Jane Austen but the new stuff ... not for me. 
I digress.
.
.
.
Can I really give five stars to a contemporary romance? 
Why yes I can.
.
.
.
Alex is the son of Ellen, President of the United States (I know, cool right??? Finally a female presidentğŸ˜‚),
Henry is a prince of England. 
Both in their early twenties, both the face of their particular dynasty.
And they hate each other.
When something happens to force them together to save global face so to speak. .
.
They end up realizing they have more in common than they thought. They are both shackled by the constraints of their fame.
So cliche right?????
Wrong.
.
.
This book has some fluff, but itâ€™s excusable somehow. 
It also broaches extremely important topics like quite obviously the rigors of fame. But also things like being true to self, figuring out who you are which I think your twenties are for.
And LBGTQ. 
I donâ€™t care what side of religion or politics you fall on, I feel like itâ€™s important to realize that people are harming themselves and worse, because they donâ€™t feel like they can express who they are to the important people in their lives. .
.
.

Most important in this life is kindness. Understanding. You never, ever know what a person is going through. Celebrities may look like they have it all, but this book poignantly points out their lives come at a price.
.

I am glad I gave this book a chance because it was just the right balance of fun and substance.
It is the first pink spine I own!
.
.
.

.
.

This is a five star read for me. Iâ€™m a true crime junkie and John Douglas is just a master in that field. This book combines procedural technique with accounts from the many, many criminals heâ€™s sat with and talked to. If not for Douglas and his team, we wouldnâ€™t have the term â€œserial killerâ€ nor the in depth access to profiling these criminals. The man is a genius when it comes to noticing everything and using it. From Manson he learned how to give certain people the feeling of power, and how to identify who needed that feeling. 
Douglas read that David berkowitz (son of Sam) had insecurity issues. So he showed him a recent newspaper featuring BTK (not yet identified) and said â€œthis guy uses your name in his letters to the police, he wants to feel powerful like youâ€.
Berkowitz sang like a canary.
.
.
.

Whether or not you like this genre or would ever read it, the research definitely has affected everything about how we track, profile and interview criminals. Whether or not we want them to, they exist. And it takes people like John Douglas, Ann Burgess, and the late Robert Ressler (the very three that the show Mindhunter is predicated upon) to do the dirty work and figure out what makes these people tick, the goal being to identify said characters before they commit heinous crime. .
.
Warning: this book is graphic in its detail when discussing its cases. I highly recommend and like this book but it is a tough read in some ways.
.
.
.
.

SYNOPSIS:
The novel is set during World War II, from 1942 to 1944. It mainly follows the life of Captain John Yossarian, a U.S. Army Air Forces B-25 bombardier. Most of the events in the book occur while the fictional 256th Squadron is based on the island of Pianosa, in the Mediterranean Sea, west of Italy. The novel looks into the experiences of Yossarian and the other airmen in the camp, who attempt to maintain their sanity while fulfilling their service requirements so that they may return home....

Magical realism differs from fantasy in that the magic occurs in a realistic setting. It is simply accepted as fact within the setting. Examples are One Hundred Years of Solitude, and even the Harry Potter series. ğŸ”¥
BOOK SYNOPSIS:

Lillian and Madison were unlikely roommates and yet inseparable friends at their elite boarding school. But then Lillian had to leave the school unexpectedly in the wake of a scandal and theyâ€™ve barely spoken since. Until now, when Lillian gets a letter from Madison pleading for her help.

Madisonâ€™s twin stepkids are moving in with her family and she wants Lillian to be their caretaker. However, thereâ€™s a catch: the twins spontaneously combust when they get agitated, flames igniting from their skin in a startling but beautiful way. Lillian is convinced Madison is pulling her leg, but itâ€™s the truth.

Thinking of her dead-end life at home, the life that has consistently disappointed her, Lillian figures she has nothing to lose. Over the course of one humid, demanding summer, Lillian and the twins learn to trust each otherâ€”and stay coolâ€”while also staying out of the way of Madisonâ€™s buttoned-up politician husband. Surprised by her own ingenuity yet unused to the intense feelings of protectiveness she feels for them, Lillian ultimately begins to accept that she needs these strange children as much as they need herâ€”urgently and fiercely. Couldnâ€™t this be the start of the amazing life sheâ€™d always hoped for?

A few weeks ago my sister and I hurriedly set up a photo shoot for a contest that I was entering.
Hereâ€™s the thing.
My sister put crap into her car and came over to help me because. Just because. 
Iâ€™m not great at helping out. Iâ€™m flaky, I donâ€™t keep my word, I canâ€™t keep promises....
My mental health issues keep me from a lot of things. 
And I fail a lot of people. Including my family. 
But damn if Iâ€™m not blessed to have them in my life anyway to do things like help me with Instagram photo shoots. Shoutout to my family. Particularly my sisters who have been there for me since they were little when I began this war against mental illness. 
We are not perfect to each other. We fight. We gossip.
But we love each other. Fiercely, boldly, we all have our strengths within our relationship. 
They both teach me how to be more human, about unconditional love and what that feels like. Before my son came around, it was my sisters who made me utter the words â€œIâ€™ll never let anything or anyone hurt youâ€. Of course thatâ€™s not how life works. But when you love someone as much as I love them, any pain they go through guts you. 
So what do I wish for you my insta friends?
........................................................................
Love so deep that itâ€™s visceral, unbreakable bonds, the beauty of bleeding with someone.
Love is all there is in this world worth a damn.
.
.

Past midnight, Chyna Shepard, twenty-six, gazes out a moonlit window, unable to sleep on her first night in the Napa Valley home of her best friend's family. Instinct proves reliable. At first her sole aim is to get out alive--until, by chance, she learns the identity of Vess's next intended victim, a faraway innocent only she can save. Driven by a newly discovered thirst for meaning beyond mere self-preservation, Chyna musters every inner resource she has to save an endangered girl...as moment by moment, the terrifying threat of Edgler Foreman Vess intensifies.

I just finished the last 20 pages or so of this book and Iâ€™m weeping. 
A blithering, blimey mess.
.
.
This book got personal for me. 
It took me all the way back to 1984.
. .
My momma gave me a box and told me to put whatever toys I could fit into it and to hurry.
It was the day we left my fathers house and never went back. 
It was the day that like Isra, my mother swallowed the fear that had been beaten and shamed into her and said â€œthis isnâ€™t for you, itâ€™s for [her]â€ -pg 336...
.
.
.
My mother married my father the month after she turned 18. But the beatings and threats started even before then.
.
.
.
She took the abuse because she was from a traditional catholic family that didnâ€™t believe in divorce.
â€œWhat did you do to anger him or deserve itâ€, was a common theme in those circles. 
My momma tried to tell her momma but was brushed off.
And she lost her nerve. The one person who should have protected her, told her to go home to her husband.
.
.
.
.
But something happened with me that my mother never speaks of, only that it gave her the strength to leave. She knew she had to get me out. .
.
I later found out that while we were packing, my father woke up, hung over as usual, but my mother poured him a glass of milk and sweet-talked him back to sleep.
.
.
She was 22. 
At 22 I was still going on yearly ski trips with my boyfriend.
.
.
I remember things from that day vividly, the last left turn that took us forever from the house on Longfellow street. .
.
My mother made it, unlike Isra.
.
.
Yes this story is about the Arab culture. But many cultures teach similar lifestyles.
.
. 
Iâ€™m proud to know a woman as brave as my mother and I donâ€™t know what I would have done in her shoes. But I thank God every day that she had so much courage. My life is different because of that brave girl so long ago.
.
.
I love you momma. Thank you for your courage.
This is a five star read by the way, from meâ­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸
.
.
.
.

I love this paragraph that Michelle McNamara writes about becoming a momma.
.
.
.
I too have a difficult history with my mother. It took years to forgive her for many, valid issues I had. And then when I knew I would never get any apologies or even acknowledgement of the past, a past which broke me into a thousand slivers, I let it go for my own peace and gave her grace. .
.
.
Michelle and I didnâ€™t have similar mothers , but it seems that we had similar experiences upon becoming new mommas. The realization that no matter what transgresses in the future, that new baby is your world and you want everything for them.
And thereâ€™s a realization that itâ€™s really freakin hard!
.
.
.
.
.
After I had my son, with my husband never leaving our sides, and also taking care of our newborn because I was out of commission from almost deadly complications, I thought of my own momma.
18 years old with a newborn, all by herself most of the time, with an abusive husband.
And then I bawled.
.
.
.
.
I wanted to go back in time, be her friend, love her, help her.
My God she must have felt so alone.
And yet she took care of a preemie newborn, figuring things out along the way. 
As I write this, I can scarcely see through my tears.
.
.
.
I knew then that I would never again hold any ill will towards my mother. Only love. 
She was so damaged from that part of her life, I canâ€™t imagine what that experience was and still may be for her. 
Perhaps I reminded her of it too much. And perhaps the naturally practical and bold human that I am, just didnâ€™t mesh with the sensitive, almost little girl qualities that my momma has.
Whatever the case, I donâ€™t care. I will love and honor that woman with everything I am as long as I have her.
.
.
.
.
.

Gettin real here. 
How many of you suffer from mental health issues? 
I do. My specific diagnoses are: panic disorder with agoraphobia and ptsd as well as anxiety induced OCD, and ADD.
It really hit when I was 25, and then again I hit rock bottom when I was 32. 
It has been a long road back to a state of health.
So Iâ€™m a momma. Lately with depression hitting I have a tough time doing regular things. I have to do things in a specific order so it takes me a while to get my son and I ready to get out. And I also have to relax a while before I start that arduous process.
Iâ€™m afraid my son is suffering because we donâ€™t get out as much as we should, or Iâ€™m not the mom he deserves.
But my cousin reminds me that above all he knows that I love him and the most important thing is that Iâ€™m here for him. He will be in school soon enough and these days to ourselves will be gone.
I am enough. 
And so are you.
If you suffer from mental health issues you are not alone. 
Tell me your story.
